I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) has requested the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  provide  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  enhancing  the 
competitiveness and efficiency of passenger railway operations. A Fact-Finding Mission visited 
the PRC in June 2008 and reached an understanding with the Government on the TA project’s 
objectives,  scope,  terms  of  reference,  cost  estimates,  financing  plan,  and  implementation 
arrangements. The TA is included in ADB’s 20081 country program for the PRC.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The annual growth of passenger transport was 9% and freight transport grew at 7.6% 
during 1978–2006. Railways represent the principal mode of freight transport in the PRC, and, 
in 2006, the modal split for freight ton-kilometers (km) was 47.5% for railways, 27.9% for inland 
waterways and sea shipping, 21.1% for roads, 3.3% for pipelines, and 0.2% for civil aviation. In 
2006, road traffic accounted for 52.8% of total passenger-km, followed by railways with 34.5%, 
civil aviation with 12.3%, and coastal and inland waterways with 0.4%. 
 
3.  Rail is the primary mode of transport for long-distance and bulk transport in the PRC, 
and  rapid  economic  growth  has  resulted  in  an  accordingly  high  demand  for  railway 
transportation. At the end of 2007, the PRC’s railway system comprised 78,000 route-km. The 
system annually carries about one third of the PRC’s total passenger traffic and about one half 
of its freight traffic. Between 1978 and 2006, railway freight grew from 535 billion ton-km to 
2,172 billion ton-km, equivalent to an annual growth rate of 5.14%. Railway passenger traffic 
grew at 6.65% annually in the period, rising from 109 billion passenger-km to 666.2 billion 
passenger-km. The average railway journey increased from 134 km in 1978 to 535 km in 2006. 
By comparison, the average journey per passenger on roads grew from 35 km to 55 km over 
the same period. For freight, the average railway haul was 770 km in 2006 as compared to 
65 km for road. Because of the spatial distribution of natural resources, processing plants, and 
production centers, railways will continue to play a major role in the transport sector. However, 
their capacity has lagged behind demand due to constraints in the railway system. Given that 
system’s  important  role,  the  Government  has  adopted  an  aggressive  plan  to  improve  the 
railways. It has planned network extensions and construction in the underserved areas having 
good potential to use rail services.  
 
4.  The Government’s policy on railway development is focused on (i) removing constraints 
and expanding the system’s capacity, (ii) encouraging the construction of joint-venture local 
railways to promote the development of local economies, (iii) improving the efficiency and safety 
of the existing system by using new technology and modern management tools in planning and 
operation, (iv) reducing operating subsidies through appropriate pricing and commercializing 
services, (v) initiating institutional and structural reforms to boost autonomy and accountability, 
and (vi) encouraging nongovernment investment in infrastructure and related services.  
 
5.  In 2004, the State Council approved the new Railway Development Plan covering the 
period up to 2020. The plan seeks to expand the railway network to 100,000 km by 2020. 
Increasing train speed is identified as a major goal. Priority will be given to developing railways 
in unserved areas and regions that lack transport and have remained less developed. The route 
network length will increase by 16,000 km in the western region of the PRC to reach a network 
length of 40,000 km by 2020. To improve operational efficiency, the Ministry of Railways (MOR)

2   
has initiated action to separate passenger and freight trains on key rail corridors. The estimated 
investments for the 2020 railway development plan are CNY2 trillion or about $300 billion. 
 
6.  The  Eleventh  Five-Year  Plan  (2006–2010)  of  the  Government  emphasizes  railway 
development and seeks to speed up railway construction. The plan envisages (i) constructing 
17,000 km of new lines so that the network reaches a total length of 92,000 route-km, and 
(ii) the length of the double-track lines and electrified lines reaching 45% of the network length. 
The plan seeks to (i) build a dedicated passenger railway network by constructing 7,000 km of 
dedicated passenger lines, with Beijing, Guangzhou, Shanghai, and Wuhan as the centers; 
(ii) develop coal transport corridors by increasing capacity of the existing lines; (iii) expand the 
railway network in the poor western region (which will reach 34,000 km); (iv) build international 
corridors  at  the  borders  in  the  southwest  and  northwest;  and  (v)  develop  a  countrywide 
intermodal  network  consisting  of  18  extra-large  container  terminals  and  36  medium-size 
container terminals. A total investment of CNY1.5 trillion (CNY1.25 trillion for construction and 
CNY250 billion for rolling stock), or about $200 billion, is planned over the 5-year period.  
 
7.  ADB is the lead lender in the PRC railway sector and has focused on the development of 
railways  in  less-developed  inland  provinces  to  promote  growth  and  reduce  poverty.  ADB 
provided 15 loans, totaling over $3.0 billion, to finance constructing about 1,921 km of provincial 
railways and 5,541 km of national railway projects plus a sector-wide intervention for enhancing 
railway safety on the PRC network. The World Bank has provided 12 loans, totaling over 
$2.9 billion, since 1984 for (i) 11 national railway projects to expand railway capacity on high-
priority corridors, modernize system-wide technology, and strengthen institutional capabilities; 
and (ii) one local railway project. Japan has provided about Y578 billion for 15 railway projects 
since 1979 to expand rail transportation capacity.  
 
8.  ADB’s strategy for the railway sector focuses on helping to (i) expand the system by 
constructing new lines in unserved, less-developed areas; (ii) modernize railways, enhance 
safety, and increase capacity to improve efficiency on key routes of the national railway system; 
(iii) commercialize railway operations in order to sustain efficient operations; (iv) promote energy 
conservation and environmental sustainability; and (v) increase railway competitiveness in the 
transport sector through restructuring and reform. The strategy will continue to focus on railways 
development in underserved areas of poor interior provinces to link lower-income regions with 
growth centers so as to facilitate pro-poor growth, a prerequisite to reducing poverty.   
 
9.  Policy dialogue has been a significant component of ADB assistance to the railway 
sector, and it has effectively complemented the lending operations. Since 2002, there has been 
active engagement in policy dialogue and discussion with the MOR, National Development and 
Reform Commission, and Ministry of Finance, and there is broad agreement on reforms as an 
engine to further developing railways within the transport sector. Since 1989, 13 advisory TA 
projects  totaling  about  $6.1  million  have  been  provided  for  developing  an  emergency 
management  system  on  the  PRC  railway  network,  institutional  development  of  dedicated 
passenger lines and local railways, tariff and organizational studies for the Jing–Jiu railway, 
enhancing commercial and business operations, marketing and business development, human 
resource development, and improving financial management and accounting systems.  
 
10.  Even  though  the  PRC  railways  have  made  significant  progress  and  notable 
achievements in recent years, they are unable to meet the rising demand for passenger and 
freight transportation. High economic growth rates and increasing urbanization are the two 
major factors driving the high transport demand. With gross domestic product expected to grow 
at 7% annually and reach $3,000 per capita by 2020 from the current level of some $1,700, and

3
as over 50% of the total population is expected to reside in urban areas by 2020, the challenges 
are enormous for increasing passenger transportation capacity and the quality of service offered. 
The PRC railways face tremendous challenges in providing affordable, efficient, safe, and 
reliable passenger transport for the various segments of the society.  
 
11.  Passenger transport on the railways has grown faster than the freight transport (between 
1978  and  2006,  the  growth  in  passenger  transport  was  6.65%,  against  5.14%  in  freight). 
Passenger transport also provides a better rate of return to MOR. Passenger transport accounts 
for only 22.6% of the converted ton-km, but it contributes 36.6% of the combined total of freight 
and passenger revenues. Given the high demand for passenger railway transport, MOR has 
developed a plan to develop 12,000 km of dedicated passenger railway network by 2020 at an 
estimated investment of about CNY1.25 billion. ADB has supported the concept of dedicated 
passenger  network  in  the  PRC  railways  and  is  financing  the  Zhengzhou–Xi’an  passenger 
dedicated line (PDL), the construction of which started in September 2005. Construction has 
already started on a total of 17 PDLs and intercity railways totaling over 7,100 km. Developing a 
dedicated passenger network was a new concept for the PRC railways, and managing such a 
network is different from running the conventional railway system that carries both freight and 
passengers on the same track. MOR had no experience in operating and managing such a 
network and was therefore looking for international experience and best practices for managing 
it efficiently. ADB is providing TA2 to (i) prepare transportation plans for dedicated passenger 
railway operations, (ii) prepare a sales and marketing strategy for MOR to adopt regarding the 
dedicated passenger lines, (iii) suggest appropriate pricing policies and a tariff structure for 
MOR’s adoption, (iv) suggest an appropriate system for transport services that can be adopted 
by MOR, and (v) recommend a suitable decision-support system that MOR can adopt.  
 
12.  Development of the PDLs is posing a new challenge that consists in their conflicting 
relation to passenger operations on the existing mixed traffic lines (MTLs). Some of the PDLs 
are constructed by choosing the most congested sections of particular corridors, which means 
the existing connecting lines bring the traffic to these PDLs. Also, a number of PDLs are 
constructed in corridors where MTLs already exist in parallel and cater to both passenger and 
freight traffic. Thus, these PDLs compete not only against such other transport modes as roads 
and aviation but also with the existing MTLs. The two types of lines have different business 
strategies. PDLs are characterized by higher speeds, better service quality, fewer stops, and 
higher fares as compared to the MTLs. In short, the two complement one another even as they 
compete. Many other passenger railway systems in the world have faced similar challenges 
(e.g. France, Germany, Japan, and the United Kingdom).  
 
13.  MOR proposes to study the characteristics of the network passenger flow and analyze 
the comparative advantages of the PDLs and MTLs. The aims are to (i) understand what 
changes in train operation planning would be necessary when PDLs are put into operation, 
(ii) learn what are the target customer groups for PDLs and MTLs, (iii) identify what transport 
products could be designed separately for MTLs and PDLs, and (iv) study the system of rational 
division of labor in the PDL and MTL organizations in order to realize the full potential of the 
PRC railways in meeting passengers’ diverse needs. Given this background, the Government 
and MOR sought ADB assistance to help the PRC railways research international experience 
and  prepare  a  strategy  to  enhance  railway  passenger  operations’  efficiency  and 
competitiveness.  
 
                                                 
2  ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Managing Railway Passenger Operations 
More Efficiently. Manila. The TA is ongoing, and the draft final report is under review.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
14.  The impact of the proposed TA is an affordable, sustainable, efficient, and competitive 
passenger railway transport system developed in the PRC. The outcome will be a strategy to 
enhance  the  efficiency  and  competitiveness  of  railway  passenger  operations.  The  TA  will 
(i) review the current practices adopted by MOR for managing passenger operations on PDLs 
and  MTLs,  (ii)  research  best  international  practices  and  experiences,  and  (iii)  recommend 
actions that should be realistic for the Government and MOR to implement. Appendix 1 gives 
the  design  and  monitoring  framework.  The  study  would  make  use  of  experience  in  other 
railways and involve active participation of railway management. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
15.  International consultants, supported by national consultants, will be engaged to help the 
Government  prepare  the  recommendations  and  a  plan  that  MOR  can  implement.  The 
consultants will (i) undertake analytical review of the form and characteristics of the transport 
organization setup of PDLs and MTLs, (ii) review the transport demand for PDLs and MTLs, 
(iii) review the impacts of role division alternatives on providing passenger transport services in 
terms of service quality and affordability, (iv) identify the key issues for developing an optimal 
model  and  method  for  reasonable  role  division  and  coordination  of  transport  organization 
between PDLs and MTLs, and (v) make recommendations on optimizing usage of the PDLs and 
MTLs in order to enhance the efficiency and competitiveness of railway passenger operations. 
The TA will be undertaken in close consultation with the Government, MOR, and other relevant 
agencies. The study will build upon ADB’s ongoing policy dialogue and the outputs of the recent 
TA provided for policy reform support.3  
 
16.  Key activities will include a review of existing studies by MOR, the Government, ADB, 
and  other  multilateral  institutions;  data  analysis;  and  consultation  with  other  stakeholders, 
including the Ministry of Finance and government officials. An international training program with 
participation from the relevant departments will be organized to learn from experiences of other 
railways. Two workshops, one each at inception and at interim stage of TA implementation, will 
be organized to discuss and review the study’s findings, and a seminar will be organized at the 
final report stage to disseminate the TA’s findings.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The TA’s total cost is estimated at $640,000. ADB’s TA funding program will finance 
$500,000  on  a  grant  basis.  MOR  will  finance  the  remaining  $140,000,  covering  office 
accommodation and the counterpart staff required to implement the TA. Detailed cost estimates 
are in Appendix 2.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  MOR, as the Executing Agency, will be responsible for supervising and monitoring TA 
activities. A steering committee—comprising representatives of MOR’s relevant departments—
will be set up to oversee implementation and provide guidance and direction to the consultants. 
In addition, MOR will appoint a project coordinator who will supervise and coordinate day-to-day 
TA activities, including to monitor progress, resolve problems, arrange meetings, and liaise with 
concerned government agencies. To facilitate the consultants’ work and ensure that MOR 
benefits from their experience, MOR will also provide adequate counterpart staff with relevant 
work  experience  during  implementation.  Workshops  and  a  seminar  will  be  held  to  review 
findings at the inception, interim, and final stages of TA preparation. A final report will be 
published when the TA concludes. 
 
19.  ADB will engage a team comprising an international consulting firm in association with 
national consultants using simplified technical proposal procedures based on the quality- and 
cost-based selection method (weighted 80:20) in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The TA will require about 14 person-
months of international and about 17 person-months of national consulting services to carry out 
the terms of reference (Appendix 3). The international consultants will have experience with 
similar assignments in the following fields of railway passenger transport: (i) transport planning, 
including knowledge of models, methods, and principles of transport segregation between high 
speed and conventional railways; (ii) transport organization strategic management; (iii) pricing and 
tariff  policies;  (iv)  sales  and  marketing  strategy;  and  (v)  transport  services.  The  national 
consultants will have expertise in railway passenger transport, including: (i) transport planning, 
(ii) sales  and  marketing  strategy,  (iii)  pricing  and  tariff  issues,  (iv)  transport  services,  and 
(v) management systems. The TA is expected to commence in February 2009 and be completed 
by September 2009. Procurement of equipment, supplies, and materials by consultants under 
the TA will follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). The 
equipment will be turned over to MOR after the TA’s completion. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Enhancing the Competitiveness and 
Efficiency of Railway Passenger Operations Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Services 
 
1.  The impact of the technical assistance (TA) is to promote an affordable, sustainable, 
efficient, and competitive mode of railway passenger transport in the People’s Republic of China 
(PRC). To achieve this objective, the proposed TA will critically evaluate the quality and quantity 
of passenger transportation in the PRC and assist the Government and Ministry of Railways 
(MOR)  to  prepare  a  strategy  to  enhance  the  efficiency  and  competitiveness  of  railway 
passenger operations.  
 
2.  The TA will (i) undertake an analytical review of the form and characteristics of the 
passenger dedicated line (PDL) and mixed traffic line (MTL) transport organizations, (ii) review 
transport demand for PDLs and MTLs, (iii) review the impacts of role division alternatives on 
providing passenger transport services in terms of service quality and affordability, (iv) identify 
the key issues for developing an optimal model and method for reasonable role division and for 
coordinating transport organization between PDLs and MTLs, and (v) make recommendations 
on optimizing PDL and MTL usage that will enhance the efficiency and competitiveness of 
railway passenger operations. The study will make use of experience in other (international) 
railways, involve active participation of railway management, and recommend actions and a 
plan that should be realistic for the Government and MOR to implement. The international 
passenger transport organization management specialist or passenger transport planner will be 
the team leader. 
 
B.  Terms of Reference 
 
3.  The tasks under the TA will include, but will not necessarily be limited to, the following: 
 
4.  Passenger  Transport  Planner  (international,  4  person-months;  national,  4  person-
months). The consultants will undertake a comprehensive review of the railway passenger 
network in the PRC, including PDLs and MTLs, and research other international railways where 
such PDLs and MTLs have been developed. This review will include to study the transport 
characteristics and the passenger traffic and flow characteristics of travel demand for PDLs and 
MTLs. The review will consider such factors as macroeconomic policies, economic development, 
and the transport environment. Issues such as modal choice, tariff policies, affordability, and 
public service obligations will be examined. Based on this review, the consultants will put 
forward a principle and method for division of labor in transport organization including PDLs and 
MTLs to realize the full potential benefit of the PRC railways. Also, they will identify how 
coordination and the complementary nature between the two can be enhanced for improving the 
efficiency and competitiveness of railway passenger operations in the PRC.  
 
5.  Sales and Marketing Specialist (international, 2 person-months; national, 3 person-
months). The consultants will critically examine the existing system of market segments for 
PDLs and MTLs. Considering that the PRC has a large geographical area and different levels of 
economic development, huge differences of affordability exist. Based on these differences, they 
will  apply  different  methods  and  recommendations  for  different  customers  from  different 
geographical areas using the lessons learned abroad. They will research the methods, bases, 
processes, and models adopted by similar railways for preparing their sales and marketing 
strategies,  including  to  analyze  and  forecast  the  markets,  sales,  promotion,  and  customer 
relationship management. Based on this research, the consultants will recommend appropriate 
market segmentation for PDLs and MTLs, as well as a sales and marketing strategy that can be

Appendix 3  9
adopted by MOR for PDLs and MTLs. This should include recommendations for the appropriate 
method, basis, process, and model to be adopted by the MOR for deciding upon, adjusting, 
implementing, and evaluating the marketing strategy, including analysis and forecasting of the 
market, sales strategy, promotion strategy, and customer relationship management. Innovative 
methods or steps adopted by similar railways should also be included in the recommendations. 
Given the constraints of supply and demand and the limitations of the forecasting, and based on 
the best international experiences, they should recommend special products or services and 
innovative approaches to product pricing and service quality that can be adopted by the MOR 
for PDLs and MTLs.  
 
6.  Pricing  and  Tariff  Specialist  (international,  2  person-months;  national,  3  person-
months). The consultants will undertake a critical review of the pricing and tariff policies for 
railway  passenger  operations  for  PDLs  and  MTLs  in  the  PRC  and  research  international 
experience  among  similar  railways.  They  will  evaluate  issues  such  as  affordability,  public 
service obligations, travel time, comfort of travel, provision of transport services, and other 
issues related to passenger amenities and quality of travel. Issues such as full cost recovery, 
cross subsidization, and others should be examined. Based on this review, they will suggest 
appropriate pricing policies and a tariff structure that can be adopted by the MOR for the PDLs 
and MTLs. The recommendations should put forward a method, basis, process, and model that 
can be adopted by the MOR for deciding, adjusting, implementing, and evaluating the pricing 
policy and tariff strategy for PDLs and MTLs. They also should examine the possibility of 
adopting a flexible pricing mechanism.  
 
7.  Transport  Services  Specialist  (international,  2  person-months;  national,  3  person-
months). The consultants will research the best international experience in developing related 
transport services on PDLs and MTLs, such as the process of works, on-board train services, 
station services, provision of passenger amenities, ticketing, information computerization, and 
passenger information systems. They will compare these services with those of other similar 
international railways. They will evaluate which of these transport services can be adopted by 
the MOR. The consultants will study mechanisms for guaranteeing service quality of passenger 
railway transportation, including institutional arrangements and standards on how to manage 
these. They will recommend a fair and objective evaluation system for monitoring the service 
quality  of  passenger  railway  transportation,  including  standards  on  how  to  make  such 
evaluations for both PDLs and MTLs. 
 
8.  Passenger Transport Organization Management Specialist (international, 4 person-
months; national, 4 person-months). The consultants will undertake comprehensive research 
and review of the railway transportation organization management system in the interest of 
enhancing the efficiency and competitiveness of PDLs and MTLs in the PRC railways, and they 
will  compare  this  system  with  similar  passenger  railways  in  other  countries.  They  should 
evaluate the contents, organization methods, implementation methods, process of related works, 
management  regulations,  setup  and  function  of  the  framework,  and  customer  relations 
management methods that can be adopted for the PDLs and MTLs. They will examine issues 
such as modal competition, use of technology and management information systems, and 
developing e-commerce. Based on this review and evaluation, they will make recommendations 
suitable for a management system that can be adopted by the MOR for PDLs and MTLs. 
 
9.  Based on the above review, the consultants will put forward an optimal model and 
methods confirming the division of labor between PDLs and MTLs in the transport organization 
of PRC railways.

10  Appendix 3 
10.  They  will  review  previous  studies  and  reports  prepared  by  the  MOR  and  other 
development partners. The consultants will review lessons learned from the experience of other 
countries in developing similar passenger railway operations. As part of this exercise, they will 
prepare and implement an overseas training program for government officials of the relevant 
departments. This will be undertaken after submission of the interim report. The contents of the 
training program and list of participants will require Asian Development Bank (ADB) approval. 
 
11.  The consultants will organize two workshops (one each at the inception and an interim 
stage) and one seminar at the final report stage to discuss the findings. They will disseminate 
the outcome of the work. 
 
C.  Reporting Requirements  
 
12.  The consultants will submit the following reports: (i) an inception report 3 weeks after 
commencement of services, (ii) an interim report after 12 weeks, (iii) a draft final report after 
22 weeks, and (iv) a final report (including key findings and recommendations [five pages]) 
2 weeks after receipt of review comments from ADB and the MOR. The MOR requires five 
copies of each report in English and Chinese, the Ministry of Finance (TA Division) needs two 
copies of each report in English and Chinese, and ADB requires five copies of each report in 
English. The team leader will edit the final report for publication. All reports will be submitted in 
both hard copy and soft copy.
